articles.headline: Afghanistan’s Unraveling May Strike Another Blow to U.S. Credibility
articles.snippet: Allies may understand the desire to give up on a failed project, but the retreat heightens the sense that America’s backing is no longer unbounded.
articles.abstract: Allies may understand the desire to give up on a failed project, but the retreat heightens the sense that America’s backing is no longer unbounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Afghanistan’s rapid unraveling is already raising grumblings about American credibility, compounding the wounds of the Trump years and reinforcing the idea that America’s backing for its allies is not unlimited.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: The Afghan Military Was Built Over 20 Years. How Did It Collapse So Quickly?
articles.snippet: The Taliban’s rapid advance has made clear that U.S. efforts to turn Afghanistan’s military into a robust, independent fighting force have failed, with its soldiers feeling abandoned by inept leaders.
articles.abstract: The Taliban’s rapid advance has made clear that U.S. efforts to turn Afghanistan’s military into a robust, independent fighting force have failed, with its soldiers feeling abandoned by inept leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The surrenders seem to be happening as fast as the Taliban can travel.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Sharif Hassan

articles.headline: Behind the Surprising Jump in Multiracial Americans, Several Theories
articles.snippet: Families across the country have grown more diverse. A design change in the census form also allowed the government to report people’s identity in greater detail.
articles.abstract: Families across the country have grown more diverse. A design change in the census form also allowed the government to report people’s identity in greater detail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau released a surprising finding this week: The number of non-Hispanic Americans who identify as multiracial had jumped by 127 percent over the decade. For people who identified as Hispanic, the increase was even higher.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Tariro Mzezewa and Giulia Heyward

articles.headline: Tap Dancing With Trump: Lindsey Graham’s Quest for Relevance
articles.snippet: The senator went from Donald J. Trump’s public enemy to his impassioned defender. Now he’s a golfing regular at Mar-a-Lago, advising the former president on his future. What is behind one of the unlikeliest partnerships in politics?
articles.abstract: The senator went from Donald J. Trump’s public enemy to his impassioned defender. Now he’s a golfing regular at Mar-a-Lago, advising the former president on his future. What is behind one of the unlikeliest partnerships in politics?
articles.lead_paragraph: Lindsey Graham’s moment, it seemed, came on the evening of Jan. 6. With crews still cleaning up the blood and broken glass left by the mob that just hours before had stormed the Capitol, he took the Senate floor to declare, “Count me out” and “Enough is enough.”
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Jo Becker and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Taliban Sweep in Afghanistan Follows Years of U.S. Miscalculations
articles.snippet: An Afghan military that did not believe in itself and a U.S. effort that Mr. Biden, and most Americans, no longer believed in brought an ignoble end to America’s longest war.
articles.abstract: An Afghan military that did not believe in itself and a U.S. effort that Mr. Biden, and most Americans, no longer believed in brought an ignoble end to America’s longest war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s top advisers concede they were stunned by the rapid collapse of the Afghan army in the face of an aggressive, well-planned offensive by the Taliban that now threatens Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Taliban Capture Strategic Cities as Biden Speeds Troop Deployment to Afghanistan
articles.snippet: With the collapse of Mazar-i-Sharif and Jalalabad, the insurgents appeared to be on the verge of a full military takeover.
articles.abstract: With the collapse of Mazar-i-Sharif and Jalalabad, the insurgents appeared to be on the verge of a full military takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Afghan government collapsing to a surging Taliban, President Biden sought to project an image of resolve on Saturday, speeding the deployment of an additional 1,000 troops to Afghanistan as he announced a series of steps that he said would protect American interests.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Christina Goldbaum

articles.headline: Doubts, Anger and Anxiety: What It’s Like to Go to School Now
articles.snippet: What was supposed to be a new, relatively normal year has become a politicized, bewildering experience for many parents, students and educators.
articles.abstract: What was supposed to be a new, relatively normal year has become a politicized, bewildering experience for many parents, students and educators.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a new school year, a fresh start with relative normalcy.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Tariro Mzezewa

articles.headline: Now Going Viral: Meeting Online Friends in Real Life
articles.snippet: Marissa Meizz became a TikTok meme after her friends excluded her from a birthday party. She decided to do something about it.
articles.abstract: Marissa Meizz became a TikTok meme after her friends excluded her from a birthday party. She decided to do something about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Taylor Lorenz

articles.headline: A Week Into Taliban Rule, One City’s Glimpse of What the Future May Hold
articles.snippet: In Kunduz, the new insurgent leaders said they had no quarrel with the people. But residents say they soon began instilling fear.
articles.abstract: In Kunduz, the new insurgent leaders said they had no quarrel with the people. But residents say they soon began instilling fear.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was his first day as the Taliban-appointed mayor of Kunduz, and Gul Mohammad Elias was on a charm offensive.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Biden Administration Prompts Largest Permanent Increase in Food Stamps
articles.snippet: The jump in benefits, the biggest in the program’s history, comes after a revision of the initiative’s nutrition standards that supporters say will reduce hunger and better reflect how Americans eat.
articles.abstract: The jump in benefits, the biggest in the program’s history, comes after a revision of the initiative’s nutrition standards that supporters say will reduce hunger and better reflect how Americans eat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has revised the nutrition standards of the food stamp program and prompted the largest permanent increase to benefits in the program’s history, a move that will give poor people more power to fill their grocery carts but add billions of dollars to the cost of a program that feeds one in eight Americans.
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle

articles.headline: ‘I’m the Only Surgeon’: After Haiti Quake, Thousands Seek Scarce Care
articles.snippet: A day after a magnitude-7.2 earthquake killed an estimated 1,300 people in western Haiti, the country, already suffering from a dire lack of doctors, struggled to help the many wounded.
articles.abstract: A day after a magnitude-7.2 earthquake killed an estimated 1,300 people in western Haiti, the country, already suffering from a dire lack of doctors, struggled to help the many wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: LES CAYES, Haiti — With broken bones and open wounds, the injured jammed into damaged hospitals or headed to the airport, hoping for mercy flights out. A handful of doctors toiled all night in makeshift triage wards. A retired senator used his seven-seat propeller plane to ferry the most urgent patients to emergency care in the capital.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib

articles.headline: You’ve Never Heard of the Biggest Digital Media Company in America
articles.snippet: Red Ventures has turned very specific advice into very big business.
articles.abstract: Red Ventures has turned very specific advice into very big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIAN LAND, S.C. — Lindsey Turrentine first heard of Red Ventures last fall, when it bought the venerable tech news site CNET, where she is the senior vice president in charge of content. She sat down at her kitchen table in Berkeley, Calif., and frantically started Googling to find out what it was.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: For Biden, Images of Defeat He Wanted to Avoid
articles.snippet: President Biden will go down in history, fairly or unfairly, as the president who presided over a humiliating final act in the American experiment in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: President Biden will go down in history, fairly or unfairly, as the president who presided over a humiliating final act in the American experiment in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rarely in modern presidential history have words come back to bite an American commander in chief as swiftly as these from President Biden a little more than five weeks ago: “There’s going to be no circumstance where you see people being lifted off the roof of an embassy of the United States in Afghanistan.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Kabul’s Sudden Fall to Taliban Ends U.S. Era in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A takeover of the entire country was all but absolute as the Afghan government collapsed and the U.S. rushed through a frenzied evacuation.
articles.abstract: A takeover of the entire country was all but absolute as the Afghan government collapsed and the U.S. rushed through a frenzied evacuation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taliban fighters poured into the Afghan capital on Sunday amid scenes of panic and chaos, bringing a swift and shocking close to the Afghan government and the 20-year American era in the country.
articles.byline: By David Zucchino, Jim Huylebroek and Kiana Hayeri

articles.headline: A Skeptical Stock Analyst Wins Big by Seeking Out Frauds
articles.snippet: The activist short-seller behind Hindenburg Research has become known for research that sends companies’ stock sinking. He says he’s not in it just to move share prices.
articles.abstract: The activist short-seller behind Hindenburg Research has become known for research that sends companies’ stock sinking. He says he’s not in it just to move share prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, federal authorities charged the founder of the electric vehicle manufacturer Nikola, which had gone public in the summer of 2020, with defrauding investors. They were led there partly by the work of a little-known Wall Streeter named Nathan Anderson.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Culture Change and Conflict at Twitter
articles.snippet: Two years ago, the company brought in a blunt executive to make things move faster and to promote diversity. Then the problems began.
articles.abstract: Two years ago, the company brought in a blunt executive to make things move faster and to promote diversity. Then the problems began.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Soon after joining Twitter in 2019, Dantley Davis gathered his staff in a conference room at the company’s San Francisco headquarters. Twitter was too nice, he told the group, and he was there to change it.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger

articles.headline: What a U.K. Staycation Looks Like in a Pandemic
articles.snippet: The classic summer holiday to Europe has been replaced by a trip to the shores of England, where business is good but owners struggle with worker shortages and Covid restrictions.
articles.abstract: The classic summer holiday to Europe has been replaced by a trip to the shores of England, where business is good but owners struggle with worker shortages and Covid restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLE OF WIGHT, England — For the second year running, a hallowed rite for millions of people in Britain — decamping to the warmer climate of the Mediterranean — has been disrupted by the pandemic. The number of flights in and out of Britain are half their 2019 levels.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Alex Ingram

articles.headline: An Iconic Bridge Sees U.S. Allies Flee Afghanistan as the Soviets Did
articles.snippet: Retreating Afghan government soldiers crowded onto a bridge over the Amu Darya River that was a backdrop for the Soviet failure in Afghanistan decades ago.
articles.abstract: Retreating Afghan government soldiers crowded onto a bridge over the Amu Darya River that was a backdrop for the Soviet failure in Afghanistan decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan — The bridge has an eerily Orwellian name — the Friendship Bridge — and a storied history in Afghanistan’s wars.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: U.S. Will Investigate Tesla’s Autopilot System Over Crashes With Emergency Vehicles
articles.snippet: It will be the broadest look yet at Tesla’s assisted-driving technology. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has the authority to force a recall or require new safety features.
articles.abstract: It will be the broadest look yet at Tesla’s assisted-driving technology. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has the authority to force a recall or require new safety features.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. auto safety regulator said Monday that it had opened a broad investigation of the Autopilot system used in hundreds of thousands of Tesla’s electric cars.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Biden stands behind Afghan withdrawal, despite ‘hard and messy’ final days.
articles.snippet: The president said U.S. troops should not be fighting a war Afghan forces are not willing to fight. Afghanistan’s leaders and military had been given every chance to determine their future, he said.
articles.abstract: The president said U.S. troops should not be fighting a war Afghan forces are not willing to fight. Afghanistan’s leaders and military had been given every chance to determine their future, he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden offered a defiant defense on Monday of his decision to withdraw troops from Afghanistan, blaming the swift collapse of the Afghan government and chaotic scenes at the Kabul airport on the refusal of the country’s military to stand and fight in the face of the Taliban advance.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Covid Vaccines Produced in Africa Are Being Exported to Europe
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson is sending shots from South Africa to other parts of the world. African countries are waiting for most of the doses they’ve ordered.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson is sending shots from South Africa to other parts of the world. African countries are waiting for most of the doses they’ve ordered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson’s Covid vaccine was supposed to be one of Africa’s most important weapons against the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Benjamin Mueller
